ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Misophonia
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Disproportionate aversive reactions (rage, disgust) to specific trigger sounds; normal hearing sensitivity.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Hyperacusis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Considered due to sound intolerance, but symptoms are specific to triggers rather than general loudness.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Phonophobia
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Patient exhibits rage/disgust rather than fear; specific triggers rather than general fear of sound.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To rule out outer or middle ear pathology.
To assess hearing thresholds and rule out hearing loss.
To review usage and benefit of sound generators 2 weeks post-fitting.
To monitor progress, mood, and social functioning 6 weeks later.
To monitor device usage, symptom severity, and social functioning at 1 year.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Baseline assessment revealed normal hearing and middle ear function. The history of specific trigger sounds causing rage and disgust, combined with normal audiometry, supports a diagnosis of misophonia.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Hearing within normal limits bilaterally (0-15 dB HL across 250-8000 Hz).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Two-week follow-up indicated early benefit from ear-level sound generators, which provided masking and a sense of control. The patient had not yet used the bedside generator.

tests.name: Device Follow-up
tests.result_summary: Wore ear-level sound generators several times; found them beneficial for masking triggers. Settings: 40 dB SPL output, various low/high cut filters. Mood improved.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Six-week follow-up showed continued improvement in sound tolerance and behavior, aided by concurrent mood-stabilizing medication.

tests.name: Subjective Report
tests.result_summary: Beneficial effect from mood stabilizers and sound therapy. Able to expose self to previously intolerable sounds (e.g., eating with a friend). Reduced self-harm.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: At the 1-year final appointment, the patient reported significant progress with symptoms and social functioning, despite ongoing tolerance issues.

tests.name: Final Appointment
tests.result_summary: Able to participate in activities previously impossible (supermarket, dentist, optician, GP). Used sound generators to manage situations and gain control. Reported satisfaction with devices and no preferred program.

proposed_items: Fit bilateral GN ReSound I-Fit 71 TS sound generators (open fit, no amplification).
Program devices with broadband sound at a comfortable level (40 dB SPL) with volume control.
Provide Sound Oasis bedside sound generator for sleep.
Encourage use of devices to mask triggers and provide a sense of control.
Schedule appointments at quiet times (e.g., early morning) to minimize anxiety.
counseling_actions: Explain misophonia involves connections between the auditory system and emotional centers.
Validate that the reaction is real and not imagined.
Advise using sound to mask or soften triggers rather than blocking all sound.
Discuss gradual acclimatization to difficult environments.
Empower patient to control volume and programs based on mood.

escalation.rationale_short: Ongoing management of misophonia with sound therapy and counseling; patient is already under psychiatric care.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor device usage, symptom severity, and social functioning.

expected_outcome: Patient reported significant progress with symptoms at 1 year, despite ongoing tolerance issues.
Able to participate in activities previously impossible, such as going to the supermarket, dentist, optician, and GP.
Used sound generators to manage situations and gain a sense of control.
Reported satisfaction with devices and no preferred program.
